MultiAgentUnityWrapperEnv1 module¶

class MultiAgentUnityWrapperEnv1.MultiAgentUnityWrapperEnv1(config)¶

Bases: shiva.envs.Environment.Environment

Unique Agent Behaviours

reset(force=False, *args, **kwargs)¶
metric_reset(force=False, *args, **kwargs)¶

To be called by Shiva Learner It’s just to reinitialize our metrics. Unity resets the environment on its own.

reset_agent_id(role, agent_id)¶
step(actions)¶
collect_step_data()¶

per @vincentpierre (MLAgents developer) - https://forum.unity.com/threads/decisionstep-vs-terminalstep.903227/#post-5927795 If an AgentId is both in DecisionStep and TerminalStep, it means that the Agent reseted in Unity and immediately requested a decision. In your example, Agents 1, 7 and 9 had their episode terminated, started a new episode and requested a new decision. All in the same call to env.step()

get_action_space_from_unity_spec(unity_spec)¶

get_observations()¶
get_actions()¶
get_reward_episode(roles=False)¶
get_rewards()¶
create_buffers()¶

Not best approach but solves current issue with Unity step function Need a buffer for each Agent as they terminate at different times and could turn the Tensor buffer into undesired shapes, so here we keep a separate buffer for each individual Agent in the simulation

Secondary approach (possibly cheaper) could be to use a python list to collect data of current trajectory And convert to numpy before sending trajectory Test performance for Multiple environments within one single Unity simulation

reset_buffers()¶
